div.p: THE Vſe of both the Globes, Celestiall, and Terrestriall, moſt plainely deliuered in forme of a Dialogue.
Containing moſt pleaſant, and profitable concluſions for the Mariner, and generally for all thoſe, that are addicted to theſe kinde of Mathematicall inſtrumentes.
VVritten by T. Hood Mathematicall Lecturer in the Citie of London, ſometime fellow of Trinitie Colledge in Cambridge.
Imprinted at London at the three Cranes in the Vintree, by Thomas Dawſon. 1592.

div.head: To the Welwillers of the Mathematicall Lecture T. Hood, wiſheth all felicitie.
div.p:
IT is not vnknowen vnto you moſt friendlie and curteous auditors, that the worſhipfull VVilliam Sanderſon, beſides the great coſte, which hee hath heretofore imployed in the ſearching out of the Northweſt paſſage vnto China, and the Moluccas, and to a relieued our countrimen in Virginia) hath nowe of late with no ſmall charge for the farther honour and benefite of the commonwealth cauſed twoo Globes (the Celeſtiall and the Terreſtriall) to be ſet foorth. And for ſomuch as the
Globes of themſelues without their vſe (which is moſt ſingular of all other Mathematicall inſtrumentes) are more delightfull to the eie then profitable to the profeſſor thereof, he did with a friendlie conſideratiō inuite me to pēne this treatiſe cōcerning their vſe, the which I thought good generally to dedicate to the tuition of you al, rather then to any one (as the common vſe is) in this reſpect. I am crediblie informed of late that certaine men, whereof one (how profoundly ſoeuer hee thinketh of his learning) not being hable ether to wright true Engliſh, or Latine, hath gone about to form an out rageous, and moſt impudent Pamphlet to my diſgrace, & to commit it to the preſſe, an other not beyng hable either to write or reade, runneth vp & downe, both the Court, and Citie (pretending I know not
what skill in Mathematical matters) ſeeking to diſcredite al mē in reſpect of him ſelfe, & me not modeſtly among the reſt. Forſomuch therfore (moſt louing auditors) as theſe men and ſuch like without any cauſe (except my well doing mooue them thereunto) haue gone about to Kendell a moſt vile conceit againſt me in your mindes: my requeſt therefore vnto you all is this, that you will friendly and fauorably peruſe this worke: and conferring it with the profite which you haue acknow
• edged in my reading, vouchſafe to be my patrones againſt ſuch vndeſerued ill willers of mine, and that ſo much the rather, becauſe in this Booke I haue ſette foorth certaine things, whereof I haue not had any direction from other authors, but haue grounded them vppon mine owne ſtudie, and experience guided
by reaſon, which if it ſhal pleaſe you to do, you ſhall finde me moſt willing, as I haue alwaies bin, to be profitable not to you onely priuately, but to my cōmon wealth publikely in what I may. Farewell.

div.head: The vſe of the Celeſtiall and Terrestriall Globe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: ALl hayle Philomathes, what newes?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: No newes Sir, but this is the cauſe of my cōming, to haue a litle conference with you touching the Globe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: You know that my mind, & affection towards all men of honeſt diſpoſition hath beene ſuch, that I am ready to pleaſure them ſo farre forth as I may. Say therefore briefly, what will you haue the ende of our communication.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: My deſire is to be inſtructed by you in the vſe of the Globe: and that ſo much the rather, becauſe lately by our painefull countryman Maiſter Mollineux, at the great coſt and charge of that worſhipfull gentleman, and • ouer of learning M. William Sanderſon, there haue bin two Globes ſet forth, and for ſo much as they are now in the handes of many with whome I haue to do, I would not be altogether ignorant in thoſe matters.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: In good time Philomathes, is this requeſted at my hands, for I my ſelfe haue beene very liberally inuited • o him to penne a Booke, concerning the vſe of both the Clobes, for the better profite of our countrymen. So •• at your requeſt is but an haſtening forwarde of that worke, which in reſpect of his liberalitie I cannot but be willing to vndertake. Goe to therfore let vs come to the matter: and to the end your deſire may be fully ſatisfied, mooue you the queſtion, and I will anſwere.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Very well: Firſt reſolue me in this, what diffe
• ēce do you put betweene a Globe & a Sphere. Me thin
• eth by the common phraſe of ſpeach there ſhould be a
difference betweene them, for I heare ſome men ſay, that they will learne the vſe of the Globe, and others are deſirous of the Sphere.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: If you regarde the proper ſignification of the worde, they differ nothing but this, that the one is the Greeke worde, the other the Latine. But in their vnproper ſignification there is a difference betweene them, for the Greeke worde 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , as it is vſed vnproperly, ſignifieth that, which the Latine worde Globus cannot. The worde Sphere taken vnproperly betokeneth ſuch a bodie as is rounde on the outſide and hollowe within (as that which is made of twoo rounde diſhes ioyned together by the brimmes) the which bodie the Latines properly call Orbis, an Orbe: in this ſence alſo is the worde Globus vſed. Moreouer the word Sphaera ſignifieth that inſtrument made of braſen hoopes (wee call it commonly a ringed Sphere) wherwith the Aſtronomers deliuer vnto the nouices of that Science, the vnderſ • anding of things which they imagine in the heauen. In this ſence wee cannot vſe the worde Globe, except wee imitate the ignorant people who not knowing how to call a thing rightly, will now & then terme the ringed Sphere a Globe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What is the proper ſignification of theſe word and how are they defined?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: A Sphere or Globe, which in truth are all on • is a round bowed Solide: ſuch a one is the whole fram • of the world conſiſting of heauen and earth.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What am I to obſerue in this definition, for th • better vnderſtāding of the preſent matter which we hau • in hande.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
You are eſpecially to note the worde (round •
and thereby to gather this, that whether the Globe be Mathematically conceaued in minde, or ſenſibly deliuered to the eye, it is contained and incloſed vnder one ſurface. Alſo becauſe nothing is made rounde without a centre, therefore in the middeſt of the Globe wee muſt conceaue a poynt to be, the which wee call the centre of the Globe, from whence all the right lines drawne vnto the vtte •
• oſt ſurface of the Globe are equall. Itē for ſomuch as the bodie cannot be made rounde without a circular motion, and there is no circular motion without ſome reſt, and that reſt cannot bee ſimplie within the Globe, therefore likewiſe in the vttermoſt ſurface of the Globe you muſt eſpecially obſerue the two points vpon which the Globe mooueth, and vpon which it reſteth whileſt it is mooued. Theſe points are called the Poles of the Globe. In the Poles this is to be noted, they are but two, they are right oppoſite one to another, they are equally diſtant from the Centre of the Globe. And in regarde that the Globes (which we vſe) repreſēt ſome principall parte of the worlde, therfore we call theſe foreſaid Poles, the Poles of the worlde and ſpeaking eyther ſimply of the Poles, or of the Poles of the worlde, wee haue relation onely to thoſe pointes vppon which the Globe mooueth, whereof the one is tearmed the North, the other the South pole. Laſt of all from the one Pole to the other wee muſt imagine a line to bee drawen through the Centre of the Globe, the which right line is called the axeltree of the Globe, which in the reuolution of the Globe neuer mooueth but ſtandeth ſtill. Thus much generally concerning thoſe thinges which are to be noted in the Globe, ſo farre foorth as it is ſimplie called by that name. Let vs now proceede to the diuiſion thereof.
The ſurface of the Globe, as wee haue hetherto ſpoken of it, is to be vnderſtood as a blancke hauing nothing inſcribed in it, yet fit to receiue any inſcription: therefore according to the inſcription of the Globe wee diuide it two ſeuerall wayes: ſo that the Globe is ſaide to be eyther Celeſtiall, or Terreſtriall. The celeſtiall Globe is that which contayneth in the conuenitie thereof certaine circles of the heauen, and the fixed ſtarres, with their Aſtronomicall appertinences. Of this Globe I minde God willing to intreat firſt, and then of the terreſtriall Globe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: By your definition I perceaue that your whole diſcourſe ſhalbe either of the circles belonging to the Globe, or elſe of the Starres with their Aſtronomical appertenences as you call them. But before wee enter into the diſcourſe of theſe matters, I muſt craue a worde or two with you, concerning the particularities of your definition, that by comparing it with the thing defined, and with the thing ſignified by the Globe, which is the heauen, I may the better vnderſtand the matter. Firſt therefore in that you ſay that the Globe is rounde, would you haue me by theſe wordes vnderſtande the Heauen to be ſo?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Yea that you muſt, & to confute that fonde opinion of Lactantius, who affirmed the Heauen to be flat, there are ſundry argumēts alleadged by the Learned, whereof ſome are probable, the other neceſſary, the arguments are theſe: Firſt it hath pleaſed God in the forme of the heauen to ſet forth a reſemblance of his eternitie, that as in this figure, ſo in him there is neither beginning not ending. 2 For ſo much as the heauē was to cōprehende all corruptible things, & without it is neither time nor place, therefore it hath receiued a ſphericall forme,
which of all Iſoperimetrall figures is moſt capacious, and fitteſt to containe. 3. If the Heauens were not rounde, but three or foure ſquare, or of ſome ſuch like figure, that monſtruous abſurditie which nature doth ſo much abhorre, that is to ſay an emptineſſe muſt bee graunted. 4. This roundnes being denied, it muſt needs follow, that whereſoeuer, and of what ſorte ſoeuer the ſituation of the earth were, the diſtance frō it to the heauē would not be the ſame, ſo that the quātities of the ſame Starres & their diſtances would be vnequall to thoſe that dwell in any one place of the earth.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: And by your leaue Sir it ſeemeth ſo: who is he that hath not ſeene the full Moone to riſe as bigge as a buſhell, the which not withſtāding being moūted higher ſeemeth nothing ſo great. Againe in a fayre day, if wee looke rounde about vs, toward each part of the Heauen, doth it not ſeeme further frō vs neare vnto the ground, than ouer our heads? So that if we ſhould make our eyes iudges of the roundenes of Heauen, wee can not auerre it to be ſo, becauſe the Starres appeare in ſeuerall quantities, and each parte of Heauen ſeemeth not to be of an equall diſtance from vs.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
In deed it is ſomewhat which you ſay but moſt eaſily anſwered, euen by a familiar example. A man reading his booke ſeeth the quantity of each letter, & which way ſo euer he turneth himſelfe keeping the booke in one diſtance from his ſight the letters appeare of the ſame quantitie, but if he put on his ſpectacles he conceaueth the letter to be greater thā it is, becauſe the viſible forme thereof is inlarged by that meanes. The like muſt be vnderſtood in the Starres, namely that which way ſoeuer they mooue they would appeare of the ſame magnitude,
were it not that neare vnto the earth, when the Sunne is readie to ſet, there is a dampe or miſte which is vnto our ſight as the ſpectacles are, whereby the viſible forme of the Starres ſeene is ſo inlarged and diſperſed, that our ſight cannot comprehende them in their proper Magnitude. The like vnto this is to be perceaued in the water, which cauſeth any thing caſt into it to ſeeme greater, than it would appeare in the ſame diſtaunce lying on the bare grounde. As for the ſeconde obiection which you make, you muſt vnderſtand this, that the ſight is not an immediate iudge of a diſtance aſſigned, but gathereth it by meanes, that is by the interpoſition of a certaine number of men or houſes, or trees, or hilles, or ſome other ſuch like thinge betwixt the eye and the thing ſeene. Which thinges interpoſed if they bee many, wee affirme the thing ſeene to be farre off, becauſe reaſon telleth vs that they cannot be contained in a ſmall ſpace: contrarywiſe if they bee fewe wee iudge the diſtaunce to be the leſſer. Hereupon it commeth to paſſe that our eye running along by the grounde and beholding ſo many houſen, churches, hilles, and trees betweene vs and the heauen, wee iudge and affirme it to be farre from vs: but for ſomuch as in looking vp towarde heauen, there is nothing to be ſeene directly in our ſight, except a cloude or two which (as the Philoſophers affirme) cannot be aboue three miles or there aboutes diſtant from the earth, therefore wee thinke that parte of heauen to be nearer: ſo that the argument taken from the equall apparent magnitude of the ſtarres cannot bee but true, and inferreth the roundeneſſe of the heauen. The. 5. argument is ſet from the motion of the ſtarres, which is circular. 6. Againe the Sphericall
figure is fitteſt to mooue, and therefore moſte •• tte for the heauen, whoſe motion is continuall without intermiſſion. 7. Moreouer by the forme of the partes namely the Starres, wee inferre the forme of the whole. 8. Alſo this ſtandeth with reaſon, that the moſt perfect body ſhould haue the moſt perfect forme, and therefore the heauen beyng ſo pure and perfect that the Philoſophers wanting a name for the ſubiect matter whereof it is made, haue called it a Quinteſſence, it • equireth alſo the moſt perfect forme which is Sphericall and rounde, as may appeare by all the workes of God, where in this roundeneſſe is eſpecially to bee obſerued. 9. Laſt of all we may take an argument from our Aſtronomicall inſtruments which are moſt fitte being rounde and are deriued from a circle. Thus much for the forme and figure of heauen.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: You ſay then that the heauen is moſt perfectly rounde: and not onelie that, but you will haue it alſo to bee accounted a Solide bodie. By the worde Solide we commonly vnderſtand that bodie which beyng made of ſome maſsie matter is not hollow within, but whole and intire through out. Muſt I conceaue the heauen to be ſo?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Common ſence denieth that conceat. For you ſee the earth, the water, and whatſoeuer element elſe, or Elementate thing there is to be contayned within the coape of heauen, in ſo much that the matter of the heauen is not intire and Solide thorough out. But to the ende you may vnderſtande this Soliditie aright, hearken I pray you vnto my wordes, and let the materiall Globe alone for a while. The whole worlde is diuided into two principall partes, the one Etheriall, the
other Elementall. The Elementall parte compacted o • the 4. Elements, the fire, the aire, the water, and the earth is inuironed on euery ſide with the Etheriall parte which is the Heauen: which from the element of the fire vpwarde is Solide and hath no emptines in any place. Yet i • it not ſo Solide but that it is diſtinguiſhed into certain • Spheres or (as we ought properly to tearme thē) Orbes, whereof each one mooueth diuerſly. Theſe Orbes are in number. 10. as may be gathered by the motion, occultation, and parallaxe of the Starres. The 10. which is the vppermoſt of all is called the primum mobile, it mooueth from the Eaſt directly towarde the Weſt vpon the poles of the world, expreſſed by the poles of the Globe, within the ſpace of 24. houres, and imparting his motion to the other. 9. it carieth them with him rounde about in the ſame time, ſo that whereas we ſee the Sunne, the Moone, & all the Starres to riſe and ſet within that ſpace, it commeth to paſſe not by their owne proper and peculiar motion, but by the violent and ſwifte motion of this firſt mooueable. The inferior. 9. Spheres mooue from the Weſt towarde the Eaſt not directly in a line againſt the other, but from the Weſt Southweſt they bende toward the Eaſt Northeaſt. Some of theſe. 9. Spheres are beautified with Starres the other haue none. The ninth Sphere hath neuer a Starre, it is vſually called the Chriſtalline heauen (although that name be common alſo to the foreſayd Sphere) becauſe it is moſt cleare, and tranſparent, hauing no one parte thicker than an other. It maketh his proper and perfect reuolution as Ptolome affirmeth in 36000. as Albategnius writeth in 23760 as Alphonſus gathereth in 49000. yeares: the which time is thought to be Plato his great yeare, wherein he ſayd
• ach thing ſhould returne to the former eſtate. Of thoſe • pheres which are beautified with ſtarres, ſome haue but •• e ſtarre, the other hath many: that which hath many is • he, 8. Sphere, otherwiſe called the Firmament, either be
• auſe beyng the vttermoſt of all (as antiquity iudged) it •• rmely keepeth in & incōpaſſeth the reſt, or elſe becauſe 〈◊〉 cōprehendeth thoſe ſtarres, whoſe diſtance one frō an • ther is firme & fixed, and not vncertaine as the other • re, and therefore alſo is called the Sphere of the fixed • tarres. This. 8. Sphere albeit it be partaker of the. 2. vppermoſt (for as I ſayd each vppermoſt Sphere imparteth his motion to all his inferiors) yet hath it a motion properly belonging to it ſelfe, not perfect and abſolutely • phericall, as the other motions are but winding from • he North to the Southward, in. 3500. yeares it reuolueth • he ſame way in the ſame time, making his whole acceſſe and receſſe in. 7000. yeares. This motion is called the motion of Trepidation. The other. 7. Spheres which ſuc
• eede are each one decked with one onely ſtarre called a Planet, that is by interpretation a wandring Starre; not that it runneth at randon vncertainely, (for the motion of them all is moſt certainely knowne, as may appeare by the Eclipſes which are foreſeene an hundred yeare before they come) but becauſe their diſtance one from an other is neuer the ſame beyng, ſometimes nearer, and ſometimes farther of, therefore are they tearmed wan
• ring ſtarres. The vppermoſt of theſe. 7. is the Sphere of Saturne, whoſe motion is complete in. 29. yeares. 155. • ayes. 3. houres. 47. min. 44 ſec. Iupiter next vnder him cōpaſſeth the Heauen by his proper courſe, in. 11. yeares, • 14. dayes. 13. houres, 12. min. 4. ſec. The Sphere of Mars finiſheth his race in one yeare, 321. dayes. 16. houres. 34.
min. 44. ſec. The Spheres of the ſunne, Venus; and Mercurie run their courſe in one yeare, that is in. 365. dayes, 5. houres. 55. min. 26. ſec. 10. thirds. 56. fourths. The which ſpace of time is commonly called, a ſolare yeare. The Moone which is loweſt of all & next to the Elementall region, maketh her reuolution in the ſpace of. 27. dayes, 7. houres. 43. min. 7. ſec. So that hereby you are to vnderſtande that albeit both the heauen it ſelfe and the celeſtiall Globe be called a Solide bodie, yet there is this difference betweene them that the Globe conſiſteth of one peece, but the heauen of many Spheres or Orbes, and thoſe as you haue hearde moouing ſundry wayes & in diuers maners.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I doe beleeue you becauſe, as the Prouerbe is, a learner muſt beleeue, but it ſeemeth vnpoſſible that the one Sphere ſhould mooue one way, and the other an other way.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It is no more impoſſible for the one Sphere to mooue one way and the other an other way, than it is impoſſible for the Maiſter of a ſhippe to walke from the prowe to the poupe, that is from the South Northwarde, whileſt the ſhip runneth from the North Southwarde.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Which of all theſe. 10. Spheres doth the celeſtiall Globe repreſent?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It repreſenteth eſpecially the. 10. Sphere.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But you ſaid before that the ſtarres are in the 8. Sphere which is the firmament.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
It is true: but becauſe the motion of the fixed Starres following the motion of the ninth Sphere from Weſt to Eaſt, is ſo ſlowe and ſo litle, that in a mans life tyme it can hardly be perceaued, therefore without any
great inconuenience we may place the fixed ſtarres in the ••• face of the Globe, though it properly in reſpect of the ••• cles repreſent the tenth.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why do you in the definition of the celeſtiall •• obe put in theſe words (cōtayning in the cōuexitie)?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thereby is expreſſed an other difference betweene that which wee behold in the heauen it ſelfe, and on the celeſtiall Globe. Our eye not beyng within the Globe beholdeth euery thing deſcribed thereupō on the outſide: whereas notwithſtanding we ſee the ſtarres on •• e innerſide of heauen.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why doe you ſay certaine circles, are there any more to be vnderſtoode in the heauen, than are expreſſed in the Globe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Yea a great many, the which I will both name and deſcribe vnto you as occaſion ſerueth. But for ſo much as theſe on the Globe are ſufficient for a yong be
• inner or a Nouice in Aſtronomie, therefore there are • o more deſcribed. Whereof one is Reall, the other are imaginarie.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What ſay you that ſome of theſe circles are imaginarie. What meane you thereby, would you haue vs thinke them to be deuiſes of an idle brayne?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Not ſo, their commoditie is ſingular in common life beyng well vnderſtood and applied to vſe: but • herefore they are called Imaginarie becauſe they are not expreſlie to be ſeene in the heauen, but are in minde to be conceaued.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Well, let vs now come to thoſe thinges which you ſaide are principallie to be obſerued in the celeſtiall Globe, that is the circles and the ſtarres with their Aſtronomicall appurtenances.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Here I will vſe a Hyſteron proteron as the Rh •
toricians tearme it, and will ſet the carte before the horſ • that is I will firſt ſpeake of the Starres, and then of th • Circles, for ſo I thinke it fitteſt for your inſtruction.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: As you pleaſe Sir, but what Methode and ord •• ſhall wee obſerue in them.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I thinke it not amiſſe to haue conſideration 〈◊〉 theſe two thinges: Firſt, of the writing which I tearme • before the Aſtronomicall appertenances, then of th • ſtarres themſelues.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
I pray you do ſo. I perceaue in the Globe that b •• many of the Starres there are ſet downe the Character • of the Planets, ſometimes one alone, as in the thighe 〈◊〉
Gemini, what doth it ſignifie.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The Character doth expreſſe the nature of th • Starre vnto which it is adioyned, according as the Character doth importe. If it be the Character of Saturne, ſignifieth the Starre to be of his nature: if it be the Character of Iupiter, it ſignifieth the ſtarre to be of his nature, and ſo forth of the reſt.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Sometimes there are two Characters togethe • as in the fiſhe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: They betoken that ſtarre to admit the nature 〈◊〉 both the Planets.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Sometimes betweene the two Characters ther • ſtandeth the letter P.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It ſignifieth the ſtarre to be of the nature of th • Planet vnto whom the firſt Character doth belong, ye • partly alſo of the nature of the Planet, to whom the othe • Character apperteineth.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Sometimes the Characters are not ioyned with any one ſtarre but are ſet downe by themſelues alone, &
before the Character there ſtādeth a letter as in the Lion.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It ſignifieth that all thoſe ſtarres to whom that ••• ter is adioyned, to be of the qualitie of that Planet, before whoſe Character the ſame letter ſtandeth.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
I finde in the Globe certaine ſyllables, but they make not perfect wordes: as Card, or Car. Alf. or Al
••• . Reg.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Card. or Car. ſignifieth Cardanus, whoſe ſtu
••• in theſe ſciences hath beene ſingular, and therfore his authoritie is great, and is often alleaged not onely for the •• gneſſe of the Starres, as where it is written Reg. Car. that is to ſay, Cardane counteth it a princely Starre, or a •• arre of the firſt magnitude. But alſo for their qualitie 〈◊〉 where you ſee it written by the bowe of Sagittarius the archer, the meaning is that Cardane accounteth that •• arre to be of the nature of Iupiter & Mars. The like 〈◊〉 to be vnderſtood of Alf. or Alfon. which ſignifieth Alphonſus king of Aragon, whoſe great trauaile and •• ſt in thoſe ſtudies hath purchaſed vnto him an eternall •• me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Let vs now come to the Starres for I ſee nothing •• s to be doubted of, what order ſhalbe kept in diſcour
• ng of them.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I thinke it ſufficient to ſpeake of their adiuncts, • amely of their quantitie and qualitie.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Then you minde not to ſpeake of the diuiſion of •• e Starres into ſeuerall kindes, nor of the matter whereof they are made.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
No, for the ſtarres expreſſed in the Globe are all of one kinde, that is fixed, and differ onely in quantitie or • ualitie, as for the matter, that belōgeth not to the Aſtro
• omer, but to the Philoſopher: ſo that whether they be
the thicker parte of their Orbe, and are to their Or • as a knot to a tree, or whether they bee made of fire are firie ſtones let the Philoſophers looke to that. I pu •
poſe onely to entreate as I haue ſayde of their quanti • and qualitie. The quantitie of the ſtarres is to be conſid •
red eyther in their number, or in their magnitude.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How many are there in the Globe?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: There are 1025.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Are there no more in the heauen? We ſay commonly that they are in number infinite.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
It is without queſtion that there are more 〈◊〉 heauen, but yet they are not infinite in number, for 〈◊〉 is written. Pſalm. 147. He counteth the number 〈◊〉 the Starres and calleth them all by their names. If the • may be counted and named, they are not infinite. Ther •
fore when wee ſay that they are infinite, our meaning 〈◊〉 that their number is exceeding great, as it appeareth. Geneſis 22. verſ. 12.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why then do the Aſtronomers keepe an accor • of no more ſeing their number is ſo great?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The heauen is to the Aſtronomer as a book therfore euen as a man looking vpon a booke lying farr • of from his ſight, doth onely account thoſe letters whic • he doth ſee & diſcerne: euē ſo the Aſtronomer, althoug • he ſee a great number of ſtarres, yet maketh he accoūt •• no more then theſe becauſe he can diſtinguiſh no more.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Haue there no more beene noted heretofore, o • ſince the time that this number was firſt ratified?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Yes, for the Portugales traueling into Indi •
haue brought home newes of certaine litle cloudes near vnto the South pole, & certaine ſtars, the which ſtars a • you may ſee are ſet downe by M. Mollineux in the Celeſtiall
Globe. Some of them being cōprehended within •• e Croſſe, and are cōmonly by our men called the Cro
• ers, ſome of them are included in the South triangle, •• hers are left in formed. So that their report argueth •• at all the fixed ſtarres were not obſerued by Ptolomie
•• mſelfe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: There is yet one queſtion remaining touching the number of the ſtarres. I obſerue that in the winter the • umber of the ſtarres ſeemeth more than in Summer: that ſhould be the reaſon thereof?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
You muſt note this that it moſt commonly fal
•• th out ſo when the weather is coldeſt, and the nightes • re froſtie: and thereby I gather the chiefeſt reaſon, why 〈◊〉 the winter the ſtarres appeare ſo many to bee this, 〈◊〉 Sommer the colde hauing no place left vnto it where
•• to be, but the middle region of the ayre, where it • axeth at that time moſt forceable by reaſon of the An
• periſtaſis of the heate, it ſo engroſſeth and thickeneth •• e ayre, that the ſtarres of the leſſer magnitude beyng • ut weake in their beames cannot pearſe it, and come to • ur ſight: In winter this colde breaking the priſon wher
•• it was pend before, & gathered thicke together, ſprea
• eth it ſelfe and becommeth more thinne, ſo that the ayre beyng more purged, and the groſſenes thereof being •• ken away, yeeldeth to the ſtarres of ſmaller light, a free • nd readie paſſage through which they may ſende there • eames vnto our ſight. An other reaſon is thus alleaged, 〈◊〉 winter becauſe the ayre is more purged, the ſtarres do • ine very forceably, whereupon it cōmeth to paſſe that our ſight may be deceaued in them, and cauſeth vs to • hinke, that wee perceaue more ſtarres than indeede wee wee doe: where as wee doe not ſee more ſtarres, but
onely certaine appearances of them procured by their vehement brightnes and twinckling, and by the wauering of the ayre. Let this alſo be an other reaſon: the nearer the Sunne is to the ground the more lightſome is the ayre aboue it, the more lightſome the ayre is the fewe • Starres are ſeene: therefore conſidering that in Summer the depreſſion of the Sunne is but litle, and in winter great, whereby the ayre in the night time in Summer, is more lightened than in winter, herevpon it commeth to paſſe that the ſtarres ſeeme fewer in Summer than in winter.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thus much for the number of the ſtarres: wha • is their Magnitude?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Their Magnitude is a certaine quantitie wherby the ſtarres differ one frō an other. The ſeuerall Magnitudes obſerued in the ſtarres are ſixe, vnto the which are adioyned certaine other which are called of the Latines Nebuloſae, & Obſcurae, cloudie and obſcure o • darke ſtarres. All there Magnitudes are expreſſed in the Globe, with ſeuerall formes ſet downe before the noſe o • the Greater Beare, ſo that hauing an eye to thoſe forme • you may eaſily learne what Magnitude any ſtarre hath that is placed in the Globe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How many ſtarres are there of each ſeuerall Magnitude.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: There are. 15. of the firſt Magnitude: of the ſecond. 45. of the third. 208. of the fourth. 474. of the fift. 217. of the ſixt 49. The cloudie ſtarres are. 5. the obſcure. 9. But you muſt ſtill remēber this, that in this account thoſe ſtarres are not cōtained which are inſcribed in the Globe according to the report of the Portugals, yet their ſeuerall Magnitudes may be knowne by their forme.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: So I ſuppoſe, but yet theſe which you haue now counted make but 1022. you reckoned before 1025.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
It is true: but you muſt note this, that com
• ōly in rehearſing the number of the ſtarres, the Aſtro
• omers omit thoſe which are in the haire of Berenice, if • hey be added the whole number is 1025.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Of what bigneſſe may the ſtarres be?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Some of them are 107. ſome. 90. ſome. 72. times • igger than the earth. But of this matter I haue written • argely in my Booke concerning the vſe of the Celeſtiall Globe in Plano, wherein you may ſatisfie your ſelfe cō cerning their quantitie.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The nexte thing to be ſpoken of touching the • tarres is their qualitie: what haue you to deliuer concerning that?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: This worde qualitie hath a very large ſignification, and may be applied almoſt to what ſoeuer is not of • he ſubſtance of the Starres. But I will ſpeake onely of • heir twinckling and figure.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What is the cauſe why the ſtarres do twinckle?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
The continuall motion of the aire: in which • here are two motions to be conſidered: the one is pro
•• er to the aire, which is vpward in a right line: the other is vnproper receaued from the Heauens. For as the Heauen is caried about in the ſpace of 24. houres, ſo doth it • ead with it what ſoeuer is moueable within it, whereby • t commeth to paſſe, that the forme of the Starres appea
• ing in it is greatly diſtracted, ſo that it ſeemeth to vs to •• aſt forth ſparkles, which we call the twinckling thereof. This may eaſily be confirmed by the water which running on ſwiftly cauſeth the Starres which are by reflexiō
• eene in it, to twinckle much more than they doe in the
aire, by reaſon that it is a groſſer bodie, and the motio • thereof is to vs more ſenſible than the motiō of the aire

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: If the motion of the aire be the cauſe of th • twinckling of the Starres, why ſhould not the Plane •• twinckle as well as they?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The reaſon why the Planets do not twinckle i • their neareneſſe vnto vs, whereby it commeth to paſſ • that their beame is leſſer troubled and diſtorted.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Doth the twinckling of the Starres ſignifie any thing?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It doth ſignifie the motion of the ayre generallie: but if it bee more than vſuall it ſignifieth winde Thus much concerning that matter, now followeth the figure of the Starres. The figure is eyther common o • peculiar. The common figure conſidered in euery one is the roundeneſſe, for this wee holde that the figure of euerie Starre is rounde, and not three or foure ſquare: of this there are ſundrie argumentes. Firſt, our ſence which iudgeth the Starres to be rounde: agayne the moſt noble bodie as I ſaide before requireth the moſt noble forme: the moſt excellent bodies are the heauenly bodies: therefore they craue a rounde figure for that of all other is counted moſt excellent. To conclude the Moone geueth vs a moſt certaine argument of this roundeneſſe: for ſhe doth not onely appeare ſo at the full, but at all other times ſhee receaueth her light circularly from the Sunne.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Yet that is not alwayes ſo, for in the firſte quarter and the thirde her light is parted with a right line.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
The reaſon of that is yeelded by the Maiſters of Perspectiue, who truely affirme that euery great circle
in Sphericall bodie ſtanding full before our ſight, •• emeth to be a right line, This therefore ſhall ſerue for 〈◊〉 confirmation of the common figure belonging to euery Starre, which is their roundeneſſe. The peculiar fig • re is that which is conſidered but in ſome, and is call • d a Conſtellation.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What is a Conſtellation?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: A Conſtellation is a certaine number of ſtarres r • preſenting by there place, & order (after a certaine ſort) the forme of ſome naturall, or artificiall thing. It is otherwiſe called an Aſteriſme, forme or figure.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Are all the ſtars incloſed within theſe cōſtellatiōs.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
You may eaſily ſee by the Globe they are not: there are. 108. exēpted by the ancient Aſtronomers which the called (informes) vnformed, yet of later time. 6. of thē
•• ue beene reduced into the figure of Antinous, and •• ree into the haire of Berenice.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why were the ſtarres brought into cōſtellatiōs?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
For inſtructions ſake: things cannot be taught • ithout names: to giue a name to euery one, had beene both troubleſome for the Maiſter and for the Scholler: •• oubleſome for the Maiſter to deuiſe, troubleſome for the Scholler to remēber. As the merchant therefore ca
• eth all his billes of one kinde into one boxe: & out of •• at boxe can fetch them as occaſion ſerueth: euen ſo the • ſtronomers haue reduced many ſtarres into one Con
•• llation, that thereby they may tell the better where to •• eke them, and being founde how to expreſſe them.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why did they bring them into theſe figures and into none other.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
There be. 3. ſeuerall reaſons which induced thē
• ereunto. Firſt theſe figures expreſſe ſome propertie of
the Starres, as thoſe of the Ramme to be hote, & drie, ſo • ſo is the Ramme: Andromeda chained betokeneth impriſonment. The head of Meduſa cut of ſignifieth th • loſſe of that member. Orion with his terrible, & threaning geſture importeth tempeſt, and terrible weather: th •
Serpent, the Scorpion, and the Dragon, ſignifie poiſo • the Bull inſinuateth a melancholie paſſion, the Beare i •
ferreth crueltie &c. Secondly ſome of the Starres if no • preciſely, yet after a certaine ſorte do repreſent ſuch a figure, and therefore that figure was aſſigned them: as fo • example the Crowne both North and South, the Sco •
pion, and the Triangle partly repreſent the figure whic • they haue. The thirde cauſe was the continuance of th • memorie of ſome notable man, who either in regarde 〈◊〉 their ſingular paines taken in Aſtronomie, or in regard of ſome other notable deede, had well deſerued of mankinde, as Hercules, Perſeus, &c.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Are theſe conſtellations of any antiquitie, & wh •• was the firſt author of them?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I neuer reade who was the firſt author of eac • particular conſtellation, we receaue them of Ptolomee and he receaued them of the Platonickes, ſo that the •• antiquity is great. Thyeſtes the brother of Atreus is ſai • to haue inuented the conſtellation of the Ramme: More ouer in the 38. chapter of Iob, there is mention made o • the Pleiades Orion, and Arcturus & Mazzaroth which ſome interprete the 12. ſignes: Iob liued in th • time of Abraham as Siderocrates maketh mention in his Booke, De commenſurandis locorum diſtantijs.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How many conſtellations are there, and which are they?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
There are 48. beſides the Croſſe & the South
••• angle, which are newly added in the laſt Globes. In the • orth parte there are. 21. namely. 1. Vrſa minor, the leſ
•• Beare. 2. Ʋrſa maior, the greater Beare. 3. Draco, the Dragon. 4. Cepheus. 5. Bootes or Arctophylax. 6. Corona Borea, the North crowne. 7. Engonaſis, the •• eeler. 8. Lyra, the Harpe. 9. Olor, the swanne. 10. Caſſ • peia. 11. Perſeus. 12. Heniochus or Auriga, the •••• ter. 13. Serpentarius, the man holding the Serpent. 〈◊〉
Serpens, the Serpent. 15. Sagitta, the Arrow. 16. A
•• ila, the Eagle. 17. Delphinus, the Dolphine. 18. Equiſ • ctio, the leſſe Horſe. 19. Pegaſus, the winged Horſe. 〈◊〉
Andromeda. 21. Triangulus, the Triangle.

In the Zodiacke of the 8. Sphere or firmament there 〈◊〉 12. according to the number of the Signes. 1. Aries,
•• e Rāme. 2. Taurus, the Bull. 3. Gemini, the Twinnes. 〈◊〉
Cancer, the Crabbe. 5. Leo, the Lion. 6. Ʋirgo, the •• rgin. 7. Libra, the Ballāce. 8. Scorpius, the Scorpion. 〈◊〉
Sagittarius, the Archer. 10. Capricornus, the Goate. 〈◊〉
Aquarius, the Waterman. 12. Piſces, the Fiſhes.

In the South parte there are. 15. 1.Cetus, the Whale. 〈◊〉
Orion. 3. Fluuius, the Riuer. 4. Lepus, the Hare. 5. Ca
••• maior, the greater Dogge. 6. Canis minor, the le •
•• r Dogge. 7. Argo nauis, the Ship. 8. Hydra, the Snake. 〈◊〉
Crater, the Cup. 10. Coruus, the Crowe. 11. Ceutau
• is, the Cētaure. 12. Lupus, the Wolfe. 13. Lar, or Ara,
•• e Altar. 14. Corona Auſtrina, the South Garlande. 〈◊〉 . Piſcis Notius, the South Fiſh.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Yet me thinketh there be 2. which you haue not •• amed, that is Antinous and Berenices hayre.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thoſe two were diuiſed ſince, and therefore are • ot vſually counted in the number of the Conſtellations • ut are reckoned among the informed Starres, as I ſaid • efore.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Doe all Aſtronomers retaine theſe conſtellation and his number?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: No, ſome count but. 44. ſome. 46. ſome. 52. ſome 72. But by the chiefeſt Aſtronomers the foreſaid number is retained.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Of which of all theſe Starres ought I to take notice eſpecially?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It is good to know them all, or at leaſtwi •• thoſe which are of the firſt, ſecond, and thirde Magnitude. But you muſt eſpecially bee acquainted with th • leſſer Beare: for the Starre which is in the ende o • her tayle is called the Pole Starre, by reaſon of th • neareneſſe thereof vnto the Pole, it is alſo called th • North Starre, and for the excellent vſe, which it hat • in Coſmographie, it is called ſimplie the Starre. An • the North pole in reſpect of the neareneſſe of the leſſe • Beare, is called the pole Arcticke (for Arctos amon • the Grecians ſignifieth a Beare) and the South pole becauſe it is oppoſite, and right againſt the pole Arcticke • called the pole Antarcticke.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I coulde wiſhe (if it were not troubleſome) th •• you would deliuer to mee the poeticall reaſons of theſe conſtellations becauſe it is very pleaſant.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It ſhall not neede if you deſire them, you m •• finde them ſet foorth at large in that litle booke whic • I named before called the vſe of the Celeſtiall Globe 〈◊〉 Plano.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Well then let them paſſe, and let vs now • come to the Circles of the Globe, and in them I woul • gladly learne theſe two thinges, what they are, and wha • vſe they haue.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
With a good will: but firſt you muſt no •
• he manifolde ſignification of the worde, otherwiſe • ou may miſtake your ſelfe greatly. The worde Cir
• le is taken ſometimes properly, ſometimes vnproper
• y. Properly a Circle is a rounde plane as Ramus
• efineth it, or according to Euclide, it is a plaine figure contained vnder one Line, which is called a Cir
• umference, vnto the which all righte lines drawen • rom the Center are equall one to an other. In this • ence wee neuer ſimplie vſe the worde Circle, ſpeaking • f the Celeſtiall Globe, but wee vtter it periphraſtical
• e in this manner, the plane of the Equinoctiall Circle, the plane of the Horizon, or Horizontall circle, &c. The worde Circle taken vnproperly, ſignifieth eyther a circumference which is a crooked line without breadth, or elſe it ſignifieth a ſurface, in both theſe ſignifications, the worde Circle is vſed in the Celeſti
• ll Globe: be they perfectlie rounde or no, wherevpon we make this diuiſion of the Circles in the Globe: The Circles are eyther perfectlie rounde or vnperfectlie round.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Is it poſſible that there ſhould be a circle in the Globe that is not perfectly rounde?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Doe you not ſee in the Globe a ſpace contained and incloſed on each ſides with prickes, which hath certaine diuiſions and goeth not on directly, and euen as the other circles doe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Yes, it paſſeth by the bowe of the Archer, and from thence aſcendeth to the Eagle, and ſo continueth to the Swanne, and to Caſſiopeia, and downe to the Archer, compaſſing the whole heauen round about: what may that circle be?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
It is that great white circle which is really to
be ſeene in heauen, by the Grecians it is called Galaxia by the Latines Lactea via, or Lacteus circulus, and by vs expreſſing word for word, it is called the milke waie •
The beſt opinion touching this circle is this, that it is the parte of the firmament, neither ſo thinne as the othe • partes thereof, nor yet ſo thicke as the Starres thēſelues • If it were ſo thinne as the other partes of heauen the • could it not retaine any light, but the light would paſſe through it, and not be ſeene: if it were as thicke as the Starres then would the light be ſo doubled in it, that i • would gliſter, and ſhine as the Starres themſelues doe but beyng neither ſo thinne as the one, nor ſo thicke as the other, it becommeth of that whitenes which we ſee If you deſire to reade the poeticall fables or other diſcourſes touching this circle, you ſhall haue them alſo in my booke of the Globe in Plano.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What vſe hath this circle in the heauen?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Firſt, it limiteth the tropicall points whereof w • ſhall ſpeake hereafter: Secondly, it is an argument vnto vs to prooue, that the Starres mooue not in the firmament, as fiſhes in the ſea, or as birdes in the aire: For if that were ſo, it is moſt certaine that the Starres which are in this Circle at this preſent, would preſently ſhifte the ſame, and paſſe aut of it into ſome other place of the 8. Sphere which neuer falleth ſo out: but common experience witneſſeth this, that the Starres which are now in the milke way, haue beene in it euer heretofore, and wee ſhall ſee them ſtill continue therein, ſo long as the heauen indureth. Thus much for the vnperfect reall circle which is but one. Let vs now come to the perfect circles of the Globe, which are not really to be ſeene but in imagination to be conceaued, vpon which the principall vſe of
•• e Globe dependeth: A perfect rounde circle is that • hich lieth vniformally betweene his termes. In theſe • ircles this is firſt to be noted, that vnto euery one of •• em belongeth Poles, and Graduation either expreſſed 〈◊〉 vnderſtood. The Poles of a circle are. 2. points concea
• ed in the ſurface of the Globe, equally diſtant from eue
•• parte of that circle whoſe Poles they are ſayd to be. Graduation is the diuiding of a circle in to certaine parts, wherof euery one is called a degree. The parts wherinto • uery circle of the Globe either is actually or imaginarily vnderſtood to be diuided are. 360. Therefore a degree in nothing elſe but the. 360. part of a circle So that whē as we ſpeake ſimply of a degree either of heauen or earth, or generally of a degree of any circle, it is not to be vnder
•• ood as a thing, that may be limited, and ſet downe by any certaine meaſure, as by paſſes, or yardes, or miles, or inches, or ſuch like quantities, becauſe it is not of a cer
•• ine greatneſſe euery where, but as the circle is greater or leſſer, ſo doth the degree increaſe or decreaſe, and is • ide to be the. 360. parte of it, be it of what quantitie ſoeuer.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I praye you let vs wade a litle farther into this matter, tell me what was the reaſon why a circle was diuided into theſe partes and not into any more or leſſe?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
The reaſon is this. The Coſmographer whether he haue to deale with heauen or earth, hath many occaſions to diuide a circle into ſundry partes, therfore it be
• ooued him to chooſe ſuch a number in the diuiſion of a circle, as might moſt conueniently be diuided by many diuiſors: now for ſomuch as there could no number be founde of ſo ſmall a quantitie, that might be diuided by
ſo many diuiſers as this number. 360. may be (for it ma • be diuided by. 1.2.3.4.5.6.8.9.10.12.15.18.20.24.30.36.40.45.60.72.90.120.180.) therefore they made 〈◊〉 ſpeciall choyſe of this number, reiecting the cuſtome •
Eratoſthenes and Hipparchus, whoe were wont to diuide a circle into. 83. partes. Neither doe the Coſmographers onely graduate a circle, diuiding it into ſimple degrees, but they goe on farther and parte a degree into 60. minutes, a minute into. 60. ſecondes, a ſeconde into 60. thirdes, a thirde in. 60. fourthes, and ſo forth vntill they come to tenthes beyonde which number they do • not lightly paſſe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Then I gather by your wordes, that a minut • is nothing elſe but the. 60. parte of a degree, and a ſecond is the. 60. parte of a minute, and a thirde is the 60. parte of a ſeconde, and a fourth is the. 60. parte o • a thirde, &c. But why did they chooſe this number. 60.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
The Coſmographer was induced to chooſe this number. 60. by the ſame reaſon whereby hee wa • mooued to chooſe the foreſayd number. 360. As in diuiding of a circle ſo likewiſe in diuiding a degree, a minute, a ſeconde, &c. He thought it moſt conuenient to take ſuch a number as beyng but ſmall might be diuided into moſt partes, and therefore to auoide the tediouſneſſe of greater diuiſions, he chooſe. 60. rather than any other, becauſe there is none of ſo ſmall a quantitie, that will admitte ſo many partitions for theſe number • may diuide it. 1.2.3.5.6.10.12.15.20.30. Thus much concerning the ſignifications of the worde circle, and the common accidents thereof, which are Poles and Graduation, now I will proceede to their ſeuerall kinds. The perfect rounde circles imaginarily conceaued in the
• eauen, and adſcribed with the Globe, are eyther great • t litle. A great circle is that which cutteth the Globe • nto two equall peeces. As touching the Poles of the • reat circles this rule is generall, that if. 2. great circles • ut one an other at Right angles, the Poles of the one • ircle are in the other: alſo, if. 2. great circles cut one • n other at oblique angles, the Poles of the one are di
•• ant from the Poles of the other, ſo farre, as the grea
• er declination or diſtance of the one circle is from the other. A great circle is eyther mooueable or fixed. A mooueable circle is that, which mooueth with the motion of the Globe. A mooueable circle, eythe lieth betweene the Poles of the Globe, or paſſeth thorough them: The moueable circles, which lie betweene the Poles, are. 2. whereof the one lieth iuſt betweene them in the very middeſt, and is called the Equinoctiall • or Equator. So that the Equinoctiall may bee defined to bee a great mooueable circle of the Globe, lying iuſt in the middeſt betweene the. 2. Poles of the world: The other circle lyeth not iuſt betweene the. 2. Poles, but leaneth towarde eyther of them, and is called the Eclipticke, ſo that the Eclipticke may be defined to be a great mooueable circle, leaning towarde each pole of the worlde, alwaies cutting the Equinoctiall at oblique angles. The two points wherein it cutteth, the Equinoctiall are called the Equinoctiall pointes, and the two points wherin it ſwarueth moſt of all from the Equinoctiall, are called the Solſtitiall points, or Tropicall points, the reaſon wherof I will declare hereafter. The moueable circles paſſing through the Poles of the Globe are. 2. and they cut themſelues at Right angles in the Poles: the one is called the Equinoctiall colour, the other is the Solſtitiall colour.
The Equinoctiall colour is a moueable great circle draw by the Poles of the world & the equinoctial points. The Solſtitiall colour is a moueable great circle, paſſing thorough the Poles of the worlde, and the Solſtitiall points, A great fixed circle, is a circle which followeth not the motion of the Globe, but ſtandeth ſtill whileſt it turneth about. The fixed circles are. 2. cutting one another a • right angles, namely the Horizon, and the Meridian. The Horizon is a great fixed circle of the Globe, diuiding the parte of the heauen which is ſeene, from tha • parte of the heauen which is not ſeene. The Meridia • is a great fixed circle of the Globe, cutting the Horizon at right angles. Thus are all the perfect great circles expreſſed in the Globe. A litle circle is that which diuideth the Globe into 2. equall peeces, and are all equally diſtant to the equator: The litle circles of the Globe eyther touche the Eclipticke, or are ſeuered from it. Thoſe which touch the Eclipticke, are called Tropickes. A Tropicke is a litle circle in the Globe, parallell to the Equinoctiall, touching the Eclipticke in the Tropicall point. Thoſe litle circles, which touche not the Eclipticke, are called Polare circles: A Polare circle is a litle circle in the Globle Parallell to the Equinoctiall, paſſing by the Poles of the Eclipticke. Thus haue you the briefe definitions of the vſuall circles of the Globe, the other circles ſhalbe defined as occaſion ſerueth.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I pray you, now let vs draw neare to that, which I ſo greatly deſire, that is the vſe of the Globe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
The vſe of the Celeſtiall Globe is eyther ſimple or mixte. The ſimple vſe of the Globe, is when we worke and performe, a concluſion by the Globe it ſelfe, without the helpe of any forraine inſtrument: and that either by
•• ch circle alone, or by two or more of them taken to
•• ather. The mixt vſe of the Globe is that, which be
•• e the Globe requireth the vſe of forraine inſtruments. And for ſomuch as theſe ſeuerall vſes of the Globe can
•• t ſo be diſtinguiſhed one from another, but that of •• ceſſitie now and then they muſt goe ioyntly together, I thinke it not a miſſe therefore before I goe any further, to make you acquainted with the inſtruments.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Doe ſo I pray you, and I will mooue ſuch que
••• ons concerning them, as I ſhall thinke conuenient for my inſtruction.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
The inſtrumēts are theſe: Firſt a paire of Calaber cōpaſſes, whoſe feet muſt be bent inward according a • you ſee in the figure. A. The ſecōd is a Square with a •• ūmet line, made in ſuch forme as you ſee the figure B. The third is an houre circle as wee call it, with his In
• ex, expreſſed in the figures C. and D. The fourth is a thinne ruler of braſſe, bowed according to the conuexi
• ie of the Globe, & diuided into the. 90. degree, made faſt at the. 90. degree to a litle buttone of braſſe, this inſtrument is called, the Quadrant of Altitude, and is expreſſed in the figure. E. The fifth is an halfe circle of braſſe called a circle of Poſition, as in the figure F. The ſixte i • an Index, which wee call a Sphericall Gnomon, the fourme whereof is expreſſed in the figure G. The ſeuenth. is a Needle touched with the Loade ſtone.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: To what end ſerue the Calaber compaſſes?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: With them wee take the diſtance of any two things what ſoeuer propounded vpon the Globle, as of two Starres, or of any circle from a Starre: or of. 2. circles one from an other.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
In what manner ſhall I take the two ſtarres, and
how ſhall I inferre their diſtance.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Stretch the one foote of your compaſſe fro • the centre of the one Starre, vnto the centre of the other, then applie the feete of your compares to the •
quator, the degrees of the Equator contained between • the feete of your compaſſes, expreſſe the diſtance of th • two Starres.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But what is that diſtance?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It is their diſtance onely in degrees, for we • cannot ſimplie expreſſe it otherwiſe, yet if you deſire for your pleaſure ſake to knowe what number of mile • any two ſtarres in the Globe are diſtant, one from an other, note theſe my wordes and you ſhall know it. Th • Aſtronomers conſidering the huge quantitie of the ſtarres compared with the Globe of the earth, haue concluded the compaſſe of the firmament to be in the outſide 1017562500. miles, and each degree to containe 2826562 ½. Therefore knowing how many degrees any. 2 Starres are diſtant one from an other, if you multiplie the number of degrees by the number of miles anſwereable to each degree, you ſhall finde the diſtance in miles, the centers of the. 2. ſtarres beyng ſuppoſed to be in the conuexitie of the firmament.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
I pray you giue me leaue to haue a litle more conference with you concerning the taking of the diſtance of any two Starres, or what ſoeuer thinges elſe vpon the Globe. You ſay, that I muſt ſtretch the one foote of my compaſſes from the centre of the one ſtarre vnto the centre of the other, and afterwarde applie my compaſſes to the Equator, the degrees of the Equator contayned betweene their feete expreſſe how many degrees the two Starres aſſigned are diſtant one from an
•• her. I take this rule to be certaine and true, when the •• e foote of the compaſſes beyng ſet in the beginning of • egree, the other foote lighteth iuſte in the ende of the ••• e, or of ſome other degree. But put caſe that the f •• te of the compaſſes ſhould fall betweene the begin
• ng, and ende of a degree, what ſhall I then ſay?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: You muſt pronounce the Starre to be diſtant (beſides the whole degrees) ſo many minutes, as are contained betweene the beginning of the laſt degree, and the ••• der foote of your compaſſes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But how ſhall I know how many minutes they are?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
This queſtion was conueniently mooued by you Philomathes, & giueth me occaſiō to deliuer vnto you a rule, whereby not vpon the Globe onley, but vpon your Aſtrolabe alſo, or any ſuch like Mathematical inſtrumēt, you may find out, how many minutes there are cut 〈◊〉 aboue the whole degrees, in this manner. When the •• ote of your cōpaſſes lighteth betweene the beginning •• end of any degree, make a pricke, where the ſaid foote lighteth: then take the diſtance betweene the beginning of the laſt degree, & the pricke, & count it (beginning at which degree you pleaſe, and noting well where you began) in the Equator. 60. times. The number of the degrees comprehended betweene the place where you firſt began your accoūt, & the place wherin you finiſhed the ſ •• e, expreſſe the number of minutes contained in the foreſaid ſpace. As for exāple put caſe that the ſpace contained betweene the beginning of ſome one degree, and the pricke made in the ſame degree, being counted. 60. times in the Equator do runne ouer. 30. whole degrees of t • e ſaide circle, then muſt you pronounce, that ſpace to
comprehende. 30. minutes. If beyng counted. 60. times reacheth but vnto. 15. degrees, then doth the ſaide ſpa •• containe. 15. minutes, if it ouerrunne. 45. degrees, the • doth it anſwere to 45. minutes, &c.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I vnderſtand you well. But againe ſuppoſe tha • the ſpace contained betweene the beginning of the la •• degree, and the pricke therein be ſo litle, that I cann •• take it with my compaſſes, becauſe (as it may fall ou • their feete will not come cloſe enough together: Ho • ſhall I then know, how many minutes are contained 〈◊〉 that ſmall ſpace.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: When it happeneth ſo, that you cānot take th • ſpace betweene the beginning of the degree & the pric •• then take that ſpace which is contained betweene th • pricke, and the latter ende of the degree. Count that. 60. times in the Equator marking how many degrees yo • doe runne ouer, ſubducte the number of thoſe degre •• from. 60. the remainder ſheweth you, how many minute were compriſed in the ſmall ſpace aforeſaid. This alſo to be noted, that as you finde out the minutes, ſo ma • you finde the ſecondes and thirds, &c. of a degree. Fo • if (the ſmall ſpace aforeſaid beyng counted. 60. times i • the Equator) the foote of your compaſſes doth not ligh • preciſely vpon the ende of ſome degree, then take th • ſpace betweene the laſt pricke made with you cōpaſſe • and the beginning of that degree, wherein that pricke 〈◊〉 made, count it. 60. times in the Equator, as you did th • other before, the nūber of the degrees, which you runn • ouer, expreſſe the ſecondes, &c.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
In this thing alſo I conceaue your meaning, le • vs proceede. Is there any thing to be obſerued in taking the diſtance betweene two circles of the Globe, o •
betweene ſome poynt aſſigned in the Globe, and a •• rcle?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Yea, that there is, for you muſt take heed of this, that ſetting the one foote of your compaſſes in the one •• rcle, you doe but touch the other circle with the other •• ote: for the diſtance betweene two circles aſſigned, or betweene a point, or ſtarre, and any circle is the ſhorteſt extention that may be: no the ſhorteſt extention frō
•• rcle to circle, or from point to point is, when the feete • f your compaſſe (ſtanding in the one circle) cut not the other in two ſeuerall places, but touche it in one onely.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: To what vſe ſerueth the Plummet line?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It ſerueth to ſet the Globe vpright, which in • ome concluſions is neceſſarily required.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Vnto what parte of the Globe muſt it be applied?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It is moſt conueniently applied to the Horizon.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Vnto how many places of the Horizon muſt I • pplie it?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: You muſt applie it vnto. 3. ſeuerall places at the • eaſt, for ſetting it but in two you may chaunce to be deceaued.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The third inſtrument which you ſpake of is the houre circle, of what quantitie is it to be made?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The quātitie according to the vſuall māner is at your owne pleaſure, reſpect beyng had to the quantitie of the Globe. The greater Globe may abide a greater houre circle, the leſſer Globe a leſſer, yet I would wiſhe you rather to exceede in the quantitie, that faile therein, becauſe we take this for a generall rule in any Mathematicall inſtrument, that the greater it is the more preciſeneſſe and pleaſure is in the vſe thereof.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Of what faſhion would you haue it?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Of this faſhion which here you ſee in the fi ••
gure C. But of what faſhion ſoeuer it is made, it muſt b • ſo contriued that it may be taken of and on, from th • Globe at your diſcretion.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Where muſt this houre circle ſtande?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
It muſt ſtande vppon the Meridian, ſo th •• the axeltree of the Globe come iuſt through the cente • of it, and the circumference of it be equally diſtant from the Pole. Alſo you muſt obſerue this: ſome Globe are ſo faſtened to their Meridian, that the axeltree commeth iuſt through the middeſt of the thickeneſſe of th • Meridian: Other Globes haue their axeltree faſtene • to the right, other to the left ſide of the Meridian: the ••
fore when ſoeuer you ſet the houre circle on the Meridian, you muſt ſo place it that the line of, 12. a clocke both aboue, and beneath, be anſwereable directly to that part •• of the Meridian, vnto which the axeltree of the Globe i • faſtened.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Doe you like this faſhion of the Index?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yea: yet if it were but halfe the length of th • Diameter it were ſufficient: but howſoeuer you make it, you muſt take heede that the points of it be iuſt in a right line, with the centre of the houre circle.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What is the vſe of the houre circle with his Index?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The particular vſe thereof ſhall appeare better hereafter in ſeuerall examples. The generall vſe is whenſoeuer there is my queſtion made of time, or the partes thereof, as of a day, or houre, when the Sunne riſeth, and ſetteth, &c.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What ſay you cōcerning the quadrāt of altitude?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
The vſe of this quadrant and where it muſt •• nde, ſhall be declared herafter in the particular propo
• ions.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What would you haue noted in the circle of poſition?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The breadth of it is at your pleaſure, the compaſſe of it is the halfe of the Horizon: But in my cōceit it were much better if it were of ſuch a Diameter, that the innerſide ſtanding vpright vpon the Horizon it may fall euen with the outſide of the Meridian, for ſo it might be made faſt to the Horizon, & the concluſions whereunto it ſerueth might be wrought the better, if there were added vnto it a ſmall ſquire of braſſe which might mooue vp and downe vpon it alwaies at right angles.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
What is to be ſaid touching the Spherical Gno
••• on, of what length would you haue it made?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
As it is vſually made the length thereof is ne
• er limited. What length ſoeuer it haue you muſt take
•• ed of this one thing, that it be ſo framed, that it may riſe alwaies at right angles from the Globe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How ſhall I finde that?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Finde ſome place in your Globe where two great circles meete togeather, as for example the pointe where the Equator, and the Eclipticke cut one an other: ſet one foote of your Compaſſes in their interſection and extend the other at your pleaſure, making therewith • or 4. priuie markes in the circles that cut one another on each ſide of there interſection one. Then ſet your Sphericall Gnomon on this foreſaide interſection, and keepe it faſt, that it ſtirreth not, afterwardes ſet the one foote of your compaſſes in one of theſe priuie markes, & •• tēd the other foote to the top of your Gnomon, if the
foote of your compaſſes thus extended, will reach fro • the toppe of the Gnomon vnto all the other markes, it 〈◊〉 a certaine argument that it is perpendicular to yo •• Globe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
The laſt inſtrument which you ſpeake of is a n ••
dle touched with the Loade ſtone. How would you ha •• it made, and where ſhould it ſtande?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Each man may follow his fancie, yet for my ſe •• I would haue the boxe made ſo ſquare as might be, breadth anſwereable to the Horizon of the Globe, the bottome of the boxe I would haue the. 32. pointes the cōpaſſe, with certaine ſubdiuiſions as occaſion ſho •• ſerue eyther more or leſſer: alſo I would haue a li •• drawne according to the variation of the Compaſſe, would not haue it faſtened to any certaine place of t •• Globe, but applied onely to the Southſide of the Glo •• ſo cloſe as may be, vnto the Eaſt or Weſtſide of the M •
ridian as occaſion requireth. Thus much for the inſt ••
ments belonging to the Globe. Now you may take wh ••• courſe you pleaſe for the circles and their vſe, eyther ſi ••
plie alone, or ioyntly together, or as they craue the hel • of theſe inſtruments.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
I muſt needes confeſſe mine ignorance in the 〈◊〉 matters to be great, and therefore I am willing to ta •• the more payne, I pray you giue me leaue to aske, wh ••• I thinke good and I will take the Globe vnto me, and b •
ginne with the Equator following from one to one, v • till I haue runne them ouer all. You ſay that the Equator is a great circle lying iuſt in the middeſt betweene th • two Poles: therefore firſt I conclude this, that the Po •• of the world are the Poles of the Equator: as for the d •
grees of the Equator, I ſee that they are. 360. and that the
number goeth on cōtinually from one to. 360. beginning • hat point of the Globe where the Eclipticke croſſing •• oth bende towarde the North pole.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: You ſay true: Theſe degrees for diſtinctiō ſake from the degrees of other circles the Grecians doe call ••• vot, the Latines Tempora, that is times: becauſe by them the ſeuerall times of the day, and night are limited, 〈◊〉 when ſoeuer there is any queſtion made of any time be it a day, or the partes thereof, it may well be reſolued by the degrees of the Equator, yet the houre circle wherof wee ſpake before doth ſerue for that purpoſe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What is the reaſon of this name?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It is ſo called becauſe when the Sunne is vnder this circle the day, and night are of an equall length.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: By your leaue Sir, why doe you ſay (vnder this •• cle) in common phraſe of ſpeach wee ſay, that the •• nne is in the Equinoctiall, and in the Eclipticke, and in 〈◊〉 Meridian, &c.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
It is true that wee ſay ſo, but in theſe kinde of ſpeaches wee vſe the worde (in) for vnderneath, or right againſt. I tolde you before, that theſe circles, which are deſcribed in the Globe, are eſpecially to be conceaued in the. 10. Sphere, and conſidering that the Sunne is in the. 7. Sphere beneath, therefore wee cannot trulie ſay that he 〈◊〉 in the Equator, &c. But when wee ſay ſo, our meaning it this, that he is vnderneath, or right againſt ſome one 〈◊〉 there circles, ſo that a right line drawne from the cen
••• of the worlde, through the centre of the Sunne, and continued vp to the. 10. Sphere, would light vpon that circle in the which the ſunne is ſaid to be. Wherefore to • eturne to my former ſpeach, when ſoeuer the Sunne is 〈◊〉 (that is to ſay vnderneath) this circle, the day, and the
night through out the worlde are equall, whereſoeu • the Sunne riſeth, & ſetteth within the ſpace of. 24. houre and therefore it is called the Equator. The Grecia • call it 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which worde for worde may be teamed the Equidiall, but the Latines following the pleaſantneſſe of the worde, haue choſen rather the Equin •
ctiall, deriuing the name from the night, & not from t • day, as the Grecians doe. This circle is alſo tearmed 〈◊〉 girdle of the world, in regarde that it poſſeſſeth the mi •
dle place betweene the poles, as a girdle on the body a man. The ſeafaring men for the excellent vſe there doe call it the Line.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: In that this circle lieth in the middeſt betwe •• the two Poles, what haue I to note thereby.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Hereby the Globe is diuided into. 2. half • which we call Hemiſpheres, wherof the one is the No • Hemiſphere frō the Equator to the Northpole, the oth •• is the South. Item the Equator lying as it doth, is the b •
ginning of all declination, whenſoeuer therfore you ſh • heare hereafter of the declination of the Starres, of 〈◊〉 declinatiō of the Sūne, or of the ſignes, it muſt be coū
••• from this circle, and whatſoeuer is preciſely in, or vn • this circle hath no declination. Laſt of all, in that the 〈◊〉 quator lieth iuſt in the middeſt betweene the two Pol •• of the worlde, wee are to note this, that it muſt need mooue vniformally according to the motion of the heauen, at no time faſter than at an other, but looke how many degrees thereof ariſe, & ſet in one houre, ſo many degrees ariſe, and ſet in euery other houre: as you you ſelfe may prooue hereafter, and therfore as I ſaid it is th • meaſure, and rule of all time. Thus much concerning th • Equator ſimply conſidered in it ſelfe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
In the Eclipticke (for that is the next) me thin
•• th there doe many doubtes ariſe. You defined it to be a greate mooueable circle of the Globe, cutting the Equinoctiall at oblique angles, and declining from it 2 • . d. 30 m. towarde each pole of the worlde. Therefore by your generall rules ſet downe before concerning the Poles of the great circles, I maie conclude, that the poles of the Eclipticke are. 23. d. 30 m. from the poles of the world. But what is the chiefeſt ende of the Eclipticke?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
The chiefeſt vſe of this circle is to lay foorth vnto vs the proper motion of the Sunne, for euen as you ſee the Eclipticke line to trauerſe the heauen obliquely, and to decline bothe to the North, & to the South poles, euen ſo dothe the Sunne keepe his courſe neuer waruing from this line, but going on euery day from the Weſt to the Eaſtwarde, almoſt one degree of this cir
•• , that is to ſay. 59. m. 8. ſec. 19, thirds, 37. fourths. He fi
•• ſheth his courſe within the ſpace of. 365. daies, 5. houres 〈◊〉 min. 26. ſec. 10. thirds, 56. fourths, which is the length of a yeare. Alſo this circle is the beginning of all Latitude, ſo that whatſoeuer is diſtant from this circle, either toward the one pole, or toward the other, is ſaid to haue a Latitude, as you ſhall ſee hereafter, and whatſoeuer is in or vnder it hath no Latitude.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Then belike the Sunne neuer hath any Latitude, for, as you ſaid euen now, the Sunne neuer ſwarueth frō the Ecliptike line.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
You ſay true: this circle alſo ſerueth for the Longitude of all Starres, or what ſoeuer elſe is called in queſtion in the heauen, the which Longitude how it is to be founde I will declare vnto you hereafter: It ſerueth
alſo for the Eclipſes of the Sunne, or Moone, as you may gather by the name, for there is no Eclipſe, but wh •• the Sunne or Moone are bothe preciſely in, or very near vnto this circle. To conclude, whenſoeuer there is an queſtion mooued of the riſing, or ſetting, or any other thing elſe concerning the Sunne, wee muſt haue recou •• to this circle, becauſe it repreſenteth as I ſaide euen not the progreſſe of the Sunne, and there is no day, but th • Sunne poſſeſſeth one degree, or an other of this circle the which degree muſt alwaies be ſought out whenſeuer there is any concluſion to be wrought concerni •• the Sunne, or the place of the Sunne.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Are the degrees of the circle as many as the d •
grees of the Equator?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
I told you before that euery circle of the Glob •• is either expreſly diuided into 360. degrees, or elſe it is 〈◊〉 be vnderſtood to be ſo diuided. But herein is a differē
•• the degrees of the Equator go on continually from. 1. 〈◊〉 360. but the degrees of the Eclipticke doe not, for they 〈◊〉 c ••
tinue but vnto. 30. and then beginne againe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What is the reaſon of that proceeding?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
That the yeare and the Eclipticke might be a •
ſwereable one to an other, as the yeare is diuided into. 〈◊〉 moneths, and euery moneth vſually hath. 30. daies, ſo th • Eclipticke is diuided into. 12. partes, whereof euerie on is called a ſigne, and euery ſigne containeth. 30. degrees.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What is a ſigne?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
A ſigne is taken properly or vnproperly: Properly a ſigne is the twelfth parte of the Eclipticke. So tha • if wee drawe a line from the center of the worlde to th • Eclipticke, what ſoeuer Planet, or Starre falleth preciſely vpon that line, is ſaide to be in ſuch or ſuch a ſigne a •
that line tendeth vnto.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What is a ſigne vnproperly taken?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: If you marke my wordes, I will eaſily deliuer the whole matter vnto you but you muſt plucke vp your vnderſtanding, for that whereof I ſpeake is not to be ſeene but to be conceaued in the Globe. Firſt therefore imagine, that in the ſurface of the Globe there were two circles drawen parallell to the Eclipticke, the one on the one ſide therof. 6. degrees diſtant from it, the other on the other ſide according to the ſame diſtance, ſo that from the one circle to the other there were. 12. degrees. Theſe circles thus drawne muſt incloſe within them a ſurface.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I vnderſtande you: in the ringed Sphere I remember it is called the Zodiacke, and it is parted into. 12. equall peeces, whereof euery parte is called a ſigne conſayning in breadth. 12. degrees, and in length thirtie, and • eſembleth that figure which the Geometricians call a Parallelogramme.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
That is one ſignification of a figure. Then imagine that from the. 4. corners of this Parallelogramme there were drawne downe to the centre of the Globe (which repreſenteth the centre of the worlde) a right line, ſo that they met altogether in one point, theſe lines with the Parallelogramme aforeſaid muſt needes incloſe a ſolide figure like a Pyrarnis: this is the ſecond ſignification of a ſigne, and whatſoeuer is within the compaſſe of this pyramidicall figure, is ſaide to be in ſuch or ſuch a ſigne according as the denomination of the baſe doth importe. Thirdly, imagine that from the Poles of the Eclipticke there were drawen. 6. great circles diuiding the Eclipticke into. 12. equall partes, betweene each two halfe circles next adioyning there muſt needes be incloſed a
ſurface like vnto that of the Globe, which 〈◊〉 contayned betweene the Equator, and the Eclipticke, the which are in number. 12. and each of them is called a ſigne 〈◊〉 whatſoeuer therefore is contayned from the one pole of the Eclipticke to the other within any of theſe ſurfaces, is ſayde to bee in ſuch or ſuch a ſigne as the denomination of each parte of the Eclipticke doth inferre, contayned in any one ſurface. Laſt of all, if from each ſide of this ſurface you imagine. 2. halfe circles to bee put into the Globe, ſo that they may concurre togeather in the axeltree, thoſe halfe circles togeather with this crooked ſurface, will comprehende a Solide bodie, not vnlike vnto the twelfth parte of an apple beyng diuided equallie: of theſe bodies their wilbe twelue, whereof euerie one is called a ſigne: and hereby it commeth to paſſe that what ſoeuer is within the worlde may bee referred to ſome ſigne. Thus much for the ſignification of the worde.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Yet me thinketh you haue omitted one ſignification: for I haue hearde theſe Conſtellations which are ſet foorth vpon the Globe called by the name of the twelue ſignes.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
You ſay true and commonly in ſunne Dials, you ſhall ſee the 12. ſignes painted according to theſe conſt ••
lations, but they are moſt vnproperly termed ſo: and in the vſe of the Globe you muſt eſpeciallie take heede that when there is mention made of any ſigne, you haue not recourſe to theſe conſtellations but to the equal partition of the Eclipticke which are properly called the ſignes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What other thing is to be noted in the ſignes?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Their expreſſion, and their diuiſion. The ſignes
are expreſſed two manner of wayes, eyther by Characters, or elſe by names, bothe of them are diligently to bee obſerued for their vſe is manifolde. Their names and Characters are theſe: 1. Aries, the Ramme. ♈. • . Taurus, the Bull. ♉ 3. Gemini, the Twinnes. ♊. • . Cancer, the Crabbe. ♋. 5. Leo, the Lion. ♌. 6. Virgo, the Virgin ♍. 7. Libra, the Ballance. ♎. 8. Scorpio, the Scorpion. ♏ 9. Sagittarius, the Archer. ♐. 10. Capricornus, the Goate. ♑. 11. Aquarius, the Watermā. ♒. 12. Piſces, the Fiſhes. ♓. Euery ſigne as you ſee excepting one, receaueth his name from ſome liuing • aeature, and therefore that broade circle in the ringed Sphere, which you mentioned before (the which alſo is to be vnderſtood in the Globe) is called the Zodiacke by the Grecians, who in their language call a liuing creature Zoon and Zodion. Yet ſome will haue it ſo called of Zoe life, becauſe the Sunne paſſing to and fro in it, procureth life vnto liuing creatures.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What is the reaſon why they choſe theſe names and none other?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Names are beſt taken from familiar thinges, wherewith wee are beſt acquainted: For ſomuch therefore as the effectes of the Sunne in the courſe of the yeare are greatlie correſpondent ſo certayne properties founde in theſe common things, therefore the Aſtronomers thought it good to intitle the ſignes by their names. As for example: wee know the Ramme to be of nature hotte and drie, carrying his chiefe credite in his forehead, ſuch is the effect of the Sunne in this ſigne. Therein he beginneth to make ſhewe of his heat, & with his heat he inferreth a drineſſe, as may be ſeene by the Marche winds, which then begin to blow whē the Sunne entreth
into this ſigne. The ſecond ſigne is the Bull, whoſe force is more than the Rammes, and his complection is Melancholicke, euen ſo is the heate of the Sunne augmented, and that melācholike humor beginneth to abounde. The thirde ſigne is Gemini the twinnes, which expreſſeth the doubled force of the Sunne, and the naturall inclination of each liuing thing vnto copulatiō at that time of the yeare. The fourth ſigne which is the Crabbe, expreſſeth the returne of the Sunne, and his going backewarde as it were: for the Sunne after he is come to the head of this ſigne declineth no more from the Equator, but returneth againe nearer and nearer to that circle and here vpon the head of this ſigne is called the Tropicall point, and that tropicke which toucheth the Eclipticke in that point, is called the tropicke of Cancer. Moreouer forſomuch as the Lion of all other creatures is the ſtrongeſt, and the hotteſt, and neuer freed of an ague, therefore the ſift ſigne is called the Lion, to ſignifie the mighty ſtrēgth that is in the heat of the Sūne, & the ſubiectiō of our bodies vnto feuers at that time of the yeare. The ſixte ſigne is the Virgin, which ſignifieth that the Sunne in that ſigne bringeth forth no new thing, but haſteneth euery thing forwarde to a ripeneſſe: euen as the Virgin of her ſelfe is barren, but groweth euery day riper and riper, as the courſe of nature doth require. The Ballance which is the ſeuenth ſigne doth import the equalitie, and equall paſſing of the day and night, which are then of one length, when the Sunne entreth into this ſigne, ſo that the head of this ſigne & Aries are the Equinoctiall points. The eight ſigne, which is the Scorpion, ſignifieth that euen as, if you take not heede of the faire countenaunce of that beaſt, you may be priuilie, and at
